bestBHT.bht: Behold my servant, whom I have chosen, my beloved, in whom my soul is well pleased. He is called a servant, not as if he were of the ordinary rank, but by way of eminence, and as the person to whom God has committed the charge and office of redeeming his Church. He shall show judgment to the Gentiles. This informs the judgment of men about the business of salvation, giving an account of the righteous procedure of God in justifying sinners.

Henry Alford: He shall show (announce) judgment to the Gentiles."
In these words the majesty of his future glory is contrasted with the meekness about to be spoken of.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Behold my servant, whom I have chosen; my beloved, in whom my soul is well pleased."
I will put my Spirit upon him."
He shall show judgment to the Gentiles.
John Calvin: He is called a servant, not as if he were of the ordinary rank, but by way of eminence, and as the person to whom God has committed the charge and office of redeeming his Church.
I will put my Spirit upon him. This explains the manner in which judgment shall be brought forth.

But in bringing forth judgment Christ is greatly superior to all others, for he has received the Spirit from the Father, that he may pour it out on all his people; for not only does he by word or writing prescribe what is proper, but inwardly forms the hearts of men, by the grace of his Spirit, to preserve the rule of righteousness.
Philip Schaff: Behold my servant. The Greek word means both ‘son’ and ‘servant’ Christ as Messiah was obedient as a ‘servant’ and dear as a ‘Son.'"
The latter thought comes into prominence in the next clause: my beloved, etc. Comp, the accounts of the baptism (chap. Matthew 3:17) and the transfiguration (chap. Matthew 17:5)."
The Messiah is the Judge and yet meek.
Archibald T. Robertson: My beloved (ο αγαπητος μου). This phrase reminds one of Matthew 3:17 (the Father's words at Christ's baptism).
John Gill: Behold, my servant whom I have chosen... who, as such, is God's servant, employed by him, and obedient to him, in the work of man's salvation...
My beloved, in whom my soul is well pleased... always delighted in his person, well pleased with his office, and the discharge of it...
And he shall show judgment unto the Gentiles... informs the judgment of men about the business of salvation; gives an account of the righteous procedure of God in justifying sinners...
John Wesley: He shall show judgment to the heathens — That is, he shall publish the merciful Gospel to them also: the Hebrew word signifies either mercy or justice. Isaiah 42:1, etc.
